Hello and welcome to 6MuteEnglish. I'm Catherine.

speaker: Neil

text: Now, Neil, you're a dad, aren't you?
speaker: Catherine

text: I am a dad. How did you know?
I am a dad. How did you know? Is it the grey hair in my beard? Is it the wrinkles around the eyes?
speaker: Neil

text: I thought that was just your age.
speaker: Catherine

text: Well, yes, maybe.
In today's programme, we're going to be talking about fathers
and how being a father has changed over the years.
But before we hear more about this topic,
our question for the day.
According to recent research in the UK,
what percentage of men are present when their children are born?
Is it A 55% B 75% or C 95% what do you think?
I think a lot of men these days like to see their children born. It's not culturally inappropriate so I'm going to go for 95%.
speaker: Catherine

text: It's not culturally inappropriate.
So I'm going to go for 95%.
Well, we'll find out if you're right at the end of the programme.
Now, Dr Anna McInn is an evolutionary anthropologist.
She studies, among other things,
how human behaviour has changed and is changing.
She's written a book called The Life of Dad.
She's been studying new fathers and spoke about her research
on the BBC's Woman's Hour programme.
She asked why men want to become fathers.
She starts by saying that there are lots of reasons,
but how many does she mention in her answer?
There's lots of different reasons why men want to be fathers.
For some of them, it's just the stage in life they've reached.
You know, they've got the house, they've got the job now.
It's time to have a family.
Sometimes they admit that actually they're not that keen,
but they're part of the once-baby.
So they're kind of going along with it.
And a reasonable number actually say they do it
because they want to undo what their father did to them.
So rewrite history in relation to fathers
and the experience of fathering
to be a better father than their father was.
How many reasons does she mention?
speaker: Neil

text: She mentioned three reasons.
The first was that it was that time in life.
The guys had a home and a job and a having children
was the thing to do next.
Another reason was that it was what their partners wanted,
even if they weren't that keen themselves.
If you're not keen on something,
it means you're not enthusiastic about it.
It's not really something you want to do,
but because it's what their partner wants,
they agree to do it.
Or as Dr. MacKin said, they're going along with it.
Yes, going along with something
is a phrase that means agreeing to do something
even though you don't really want to do it.
It's interesting that Dr. MacKin said
that some men admit to this.
To admit to something is to say or agree that something's true
even if you're perhaps ashamed of it
or you don't want it to be true.
There was one more reason she mentioned
and that was that some men become parents
because they want to be a better father
than their own father had been.
Let's listen again.
There's lots of different reasons why men want to be fathers.
For some of them, it's just the stage in life they've reached.
You know, they've got the house, they've got the job now.
It's time to have a family.
Sometimes they admit that actually they're not that keen
but they're partner wants a baby.
So they're kind of going along with it.
And a reasonable number actually say they do it
because they want to undo what their father did to them.
So rewrite history in relation to fathers
and the experience of fathering
to be a better father than their father was.
So what is it about some fathers own dads
that they didn't like?
Is Dr. MacKin again?
Well, in some cases, you know, the father would be neglectful.
Some fathers were absent.
And others, they just felt that they were a very,
I suppose we'd say, 1950s father.
So distant, disciplinary,
and not actually involved in their child's daily life
and certainly not involved in their care.
So today's generation fathers,
even in the 10 years that I've been studying dads,
we've seen a massive evolution
in how hands on fathers are.
She talks there about some negative characteristics
associated with dads in the past.
She suggests that some fathers didn't have
a very close relationship with their sons.
They were absent, which means they weren't at home a lot
and didn't spend time with their children.
Yes. And some fathers
were seen as disciplinarian.
That's described someone who's main communication
with their children was to give them strict rules
and tell them off or punish them
if they do something wrong.
These days, according to Dr. MacKin,
fathers are much more hands on.
This phrase means they are much more involved
with their children and share bringing up
their children with their partners.
I'm talking of sharing.
Neil, come on.
It's time to tell me the answer to today's question.
Yes, indeed.
According to recent research in the UK,
what is the percentage of fathers
who are there when their children are born?
And I said a very optimistic 95%.

text: Being optimistic is good obviously because you are correct.
speaker: Neil

text: because you are correct.
Yay!
That's fantastic!

text: our review of today's vocabulary.
We started off with admit two.
For when you say something's true,
even if it might make you look a little bit bad.
And before we go on, I have to admit,
Neil, that it was me who ate your biscuits.
Which one?
speaker: Neil

text: The one you left on the desk.
Ah, that's all right.
I wasn't really keen on it anyway.
It had been on the floor.
What?
Ooh.
Yeah, well, serves you right.
And to be keen on something is our next phrase,
meaning being very interested in
and enthusiastic about something.
Then we had to go along with something.
This is when you were great to do something,
even if you're not keen on it.
An absent father is one who is not at home to spend time with his children.
speaker: absent father

text: to spend time with his children.
